utterance.speaker: Villager
utterance.content: Dr. Sebastian!

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: Two pallets of antibiotics for tuberculosis.

utterance.speaker: Villager
utterance.content: We’ve got six pallets worth of patients!

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: Stoia Tucker needs a math lesson. I’m headed back tomorrow. I’ve got some very special medicine here; this is from Hershey, Pennsylvania. One per person; one per person.

utterance.speaker: Villager 2
utterance.content: Help, help! Dr. Sebastian, come quickly! My son, he fell. He fell on this rock. We were just waiting for his friends.

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: I got no breathing sounds on the left – give me that. Yeah, he’s going to be okay.

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: The fall didn’t cause him to drop a lung; the lung caused him to fall. TB chewed it up. He’ll be lucky to live another year. Now, this is Sarni. I picked up the tab for the back brace myself. The funny thing is that the brace cost more than the medicine that would have prevented her from needing it. It’s your medicine. All of the antibiotics that we need are right there in your warehouses, in your factories.

utterance.speaker: Jerry
utterance.content: We provide over 10,000 doses a year.

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: Which is not enough.

utterance.speaker: Jerry
utterance.content: You know we’d love to do more, but our hands are tied.

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: New car, Jerry? I saw it on the way in, looks beautiful.

utterance.speaker: Jerry
utterance.content: Don’t make this personal.

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: All the way from Germany, too, I know that’s a lot of red tape.

utterance.speaker: Jerry
utterance.content: I’m not like you; I’m not ashamed of making a living.

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: And I know you didn’t become a chem. major for the money. Now you want the same things that I want, you just… You have to, you just have to push a little, you have to push a little bit harder, harder for them.

utterance.speaker: Jerry
utterance.content: Sebastian? Call 911! Isn’t someone here a doctor?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Selling subscriptions? I heard twenty and you get a new bike.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Dr. Sebastian Charles collapsed during a presentation at Stoia Tucker.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Really? Crushed under the weight of his own ego?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Wow. Is there nobody you admire?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, there was this gal I met in ‘Nam who could blow out a candle without using her –

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: He thinks it’s TB.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Good thing he’s not the syphilis expert.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: He wants a second opinion.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Second to his own. Okay. It’s not TB.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What is it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, you want specifics?

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: Lemma. Big Knicks fan.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You’ve never had an episode like this before?

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: No. He died last month. Stupidly tried to share his meds with his cousin and they only had enough for one. Dr. House, I’m Sebastian Charles.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Patients aren’t usually part of the diagnostic process.

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: Well, I’m a doctor…. Listen, I know you guys don’t make a lot of money, but–

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I wrote your people a check last month.

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: Oh, well… write us another one.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Talk to Chase, he’s rich.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: My dad, not me.

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: Every minute, four people die of TB.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wow, how can you sleep at night?

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: There’re people dying in Africa of a disease that we cured over –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, I know. I saw the concert. Seriously, let’s say you sleep six hours; that means every night you kill 1440 people. I guess you got to get some sleep, but come on, if you’d stayed up another 10 minutes you could have saved 40 lives. Do you send notes to the families in the morning? That’s going to take at least ten minutes so that’s another 40 dead, another 40 notes…. Why don’t you go wrack yourself with guilt in your own room?

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: No, thanks, I’ll stay. I’d like to hear the differential.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Dr. Cameron, tell the doctor why it’s not a good idea for the patient to be here.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He’s an immunologist and a TB expert.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’ll be very useful if we need somebody to say the words, “I think it’s TB.” What is that?

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: Oh that. I’m sorry, that’s my body powder. It’s the only thing I’ve found that works in the Sahara. I, I’m kind of used to it, I don’t even notice it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Who thinks it smells like an elephant dung smoothie?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It smells okay to me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That is exactly why the patient shouldn’t be in the room. If you can’t tell a man that his cologne makes you want to puke, how are you going to tell him that he’s an idiot?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He’s not an idiot.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sure, you say that now, while he’s in the room.

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: Look, I don’t have time for this. It’s TB.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nope. The symptoms are too varied.

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: Well, if you haven’t seen 10,000 cases I’d agree that’s what you’d think.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Told you he’s an idiot. You said you wanted a second opinion.

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: No, actually. My backers wanted a second opinion.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, doesn’t look good if you drop dead while wearing your shoes sponsor’s logo.

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: It’s TB, and I’m not dying. I’m going to want you to plan a PPD and induce sputum to confirm the TB. Imaging studies will determine the progress, and I think we should probably take a CT-scan of my lungs just so that nobody second-guesses us?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wouldn’t want that.

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: Hello? No, I’m feeling much better. Well, what you can do is you can get your board to approve the increased med shipments that – No, no, no, no, don’t try. No, no, don’t do your best. Just get it done, okay? That’s Stoia Tucker, and they’re the nice pharmaceutical company.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I’m sorry, but it’s against hospital regs.

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: Oh, I need the phone.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Why don’t we focus on getting you better right now?

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: What are you going to do, throw me out?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No, just the phone.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Sorry, we’ve got an emergency.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: There’s a phone in your room.

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: Yeah, I figured that there would be.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Right, I just thought, it’s not like the hospitals that you might used to in Africa. I don’t know what the facilities were like…

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You’re welcome.

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: And thanks for that check.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I should go.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The nameless poor have a face, and it’s a pompous white man.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Yeah, what a jerk, saving all those lives like that.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What’s the emergency?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I can’t remember how to do Walk the Dog. The guy’s sick, he may be dying. We’ve forgotten all about doing a differential diagnosis.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You just sent us off to test him for –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I had to get him out of there. Now we can all sit around and call him an idiot. Who wants to go first?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He’s right! Tuberculosis could present in hundreds of different ways!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, by that logic, everyone in the hospital should be treated.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Not everyone in the hospital’s been exposed to it for the last 20 years.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: TB takes years to kill you. Two weeks ago he was perfectly healthy, now he’s got a white board full of symptoms.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: What about something metabolic?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Welcome aboard the Good Ship Asskisser. Nice day for a sail. Pucker up, me hearties.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It’s not metabolic. Kidney, liver and thyroid are all normal. No diabetes.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: What about his heart?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Obviously big as all out doors.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Abnormal heart rhythm. White form showed P-R variability.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s subtle, but it’s there.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You think it’s his heart? Sick sinus syndrome?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Loose throttle. Sometimes beats too fast, sometimes too slow.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Causing him to pass out.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It would account for the episode. I’ll put him on telemetry; do a stress test and an echocardiogram.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Treat him like every other hospital patient. I want to see that pious, body powered toosh hanging out of his gown.

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: Could you give me a hand with this thing? I don’t recall asking for a stress test or an echocardiogram.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: What are you going to do, walk out? Corporate sponsors aren’t going to like that. I need your forearm.

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: What’s House thinking?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Sick sinus syndrome.

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: Well, that’s a lot more serious than TB. Is that a PPD?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: If it changes colour in the next 48 hours –

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: Yeah, uh, if House doesn’t think it’s TB why would he have you test for that?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Just covering all his bases, I guess.

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: Uh huh. He doesn’t seem like a guy who, who does that.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We have you scheduled for a 10:30 echo.

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: Good for you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Every minute that we refuse to love one another, another puppy cries another tear.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You’re just mad that he’s closer to a Nobel Prize than you are.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And yet I’ve nailed more Swedish babes. Crazy, crazy world.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It’s not just a trip to Stockholm, you know. It comes with a cash prize.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Seriously? No wonder everyone’s going after that peace thing.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: He cures thousands of people every year, you cure, what? 30?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: McDonald’s makes a better hamburger than your mother because they make more?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Oh, I see! So you hate him because the lives he saves aren’t as good as the lives you save.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yup, that’s the reason. Nobel invented dynamite. I won’t accept his blood money.

utterance.speaker: Mandy
utterance.content: The top of my head’s killing me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hmmm. We spent a week doing ‘top of head’ in Anatomy. I know just where it is.

utterance.speaker: Mandy
utterance.content: Ow! That is not the top of my head!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Eh, close enough for clinic. Your sinuses are clogged. Judging by the scratches on your hands, I’m guessing a new cat.

utterance.speaker: Mandy
utterance.content: It was my mother’s. She’s dead.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You keep a dead cat?

utterance.speaker: Mandy
utterance.content: No. My mother’s dead.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh. Poor cat. You’re allergic. We can control it with antihistamine, one pill a day.

utterance.speaker: Mandy
utterance.content: Pills?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You don’t like to swallow. Not surprised. Forget the pills. I’ll give you a nasal spray.

utterance.speaker: Mandy
utterance.content: Steroids? Is there something else you can give me?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, if you lived by the river, I’ve got a bag.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Hey, stress test was normal.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But his EKG was not normal.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Echo’s normal.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Two for you, one for me. We need a tie-breaker.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Echo and stress test are more reliable.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Tilt-table test.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Never works.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Bet you a week’s clinic duty it does.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Hah hah, you’re on.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You like this guy?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You always tell us our opinion of the patient is irrelevant.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Medically, it’s irrelevant. That says something about you.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You figure that anybody that gives a crap about people in Africa must be full of it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes. There’s an evolutionary imperative why we give a crap about our family and friends. And there’s an evolutionary imperative why we don’t give a crap about anybody else. If we loved all people indiscriminately, we couldn’t function.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Hmmm. So, the great humanitarian’s as selfish as the rest of us.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Just not as honest about it.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You also always tell us motives are irrelevant. Dr. Charles, your heart’s handling the changes in orientation just fine. No pauses on your EKG. And House drives up for the lay-up and oh, rejected!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What does this knobby thing do?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I’m within protocol range; you’re not going to get a different result.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The way I figure it is, if this could show you problems at 6, imagine what could happen if you crank it to10.

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: House, is that you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Does it go to 11?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Would you stop? You lost. I’m scheduled for clinic duty Thursday and Friday.

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: All right, I’m beginning to feel nauseous.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Would you turn the damn thing off before you break it?

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: Okay, I’m getting dizzy, I can’t see, I’m gonna pass out.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I win.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: At those speeds, astronauts throw up.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m not talking about the nausea.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The test revealed problem.

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: Yeah? House is insane? What he just did –

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Abusive and unprofessional. If he hadn’t done it, we wouldn’t have seen the problem. You’ve got an abnormal P-R interval. It could be dangerous, possibly fatal, particularly if you’re in Africa away from advanced medicine.

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: I’m going to need a pacemaker?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You’re scheduled for surgery this afternoon.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You’ll be able to maintain your pacemaker from anywhere; you just need to get yourself to a phone line every few months.

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: Better yet, you could join me at one of my clinics.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I’m kind of spoiled.

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: Well, we’ll get you a hut with a view. You like sand?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I meant medically. No PET scans, no MRIs…

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: This is ridiculous.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Dr. Charles, wait –

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: I know, I know, hospital regulations. Darling – – have a seat. Come on.

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: You’re smart, you’ll adapt… we going up or down?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Basement.

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: All right. You might even find that without the technological crutches you become a better diagnostician. My heart can handle this, right?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: So far just carnival rides have set you off.

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: When you meet these people it changes you. We should talk about it over dinner.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Are you asking me to Africa or on a date?

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: Oh, I can ask you halfway across the world, I can’t ask you to a restaurant a block away?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Well, one’s a job, and thee other’s…

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: Yeah, hospital regs, you can’t date patients, right, I wouldn’t want to risk your precious objectivity. You haven’t answered either question, by the way.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You don’t think objectivity’s important?

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: I think doctors like House cling to objectivity like a three-year-old to a blanket; don’t get too worked up, stay calm, stay cool and maintain that correct perspective. The only flaw in their argument is when you have millions of people dying the correct perspective is to be yelling at the top of your lungs. Sorry, my heads killing me.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Here, sit on the step.

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: So, you gonna go out with me or not?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Your heart rate’s normal.

utterance.speaker: Sebastian
utterance.content: Yeah, of course it is, it’s one flight of stairs. I’m going to be fine. My hand’s a little –

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Call a code! Second floor stairwell!

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You were wrong.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hey, I have feelings. I’m trying my best. Isn’t that enough for you?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: The abnormal was real…

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It’s not sick sinus syndrome.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, thank God we found out before we put the pacemaker in. And thank God you dragged him into a stairwell to get his heart racing.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We were taking the stairs; they keep them in the stairwell.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: The guy’s a selfish jerk, why would you –

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Why would you say he’s selfish?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because he’s been talking to Foreman.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No I haven’t, I’m just giving my opinion. This kind of altruism doesn’t just naturally –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Excellent briefing.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Hey, the guy’s still sick. Can we talk about that? The headaches point to a neurological problem. Acoustic neuroma. Brian tumour causes dizziness, loss of consciousness, messes with breathing patterns, heart rhythms –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Get an MRI. Hello? Oh, I’m sorry, I’ll be right down. No problem, I’ll do an extra hour to make up. I’m late for my clinic duty. Here, go be me for a couple hours.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Explosive diarrhoea, fever… it’s probably the flu.

utterance.speaker: Cecelia
utterance.content: Wow, you’re good. You a Harvard boy?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You’re not Hale, Oliver?

utterance.speaker: Cecelia
utterance.content: No. Carter, Cecelia.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: They put you in the wrong room, Cecelia.

utterance.speaker: Cecelia
utterance.content: Mrs. Carter.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Sorry. I’ll just be a few minutes; don’t take these in order and everything falls apart.

utterance.speaker: Cecelia
utterance.content: I have cancer. I felt a lump.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I’ll go get a nurse.

utterance.speaker: Cecelia
utterance.content: Yeah, see you in an hour or two.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Lie flat. Lift your left arm up and under your head? Right there?

utterance.speaker: Cecelia
utterance.content: Yeah, I felt it this morning. Oh, my cousin had the same thing.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It’s nothing. We should check it again on your next cycle, but you really don’t have anything to worry about.

utterance.speaker: Cecelia
utterance.content: That’s what they told Donna. She was dead in six months.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Look, the edges are smooth, it has mobility, it has all the earmarks of a benign…

utterance.speaker: Cecelia
utterance.content: Why should I believe you? Because you’re trying to rush me out of here?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The risks of a false positive on a biopsy outweigh –

utterance.speaker: Cecelia
utterance.content: Either you do the biopsy or I talk to your superior. Which is it – Dr. House?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I’ll arrange the biopsy.

utterance.speaker: Cecelia
utterance.content: Thanks.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He asked me out.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I’m shocked. I’m shocked when patients don’t ask you out.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He also asked me to come to Africa.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Boy, he moves fast.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I think the two questions had two different objectives.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Well, do you like him?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Good looking single guy, genius doctor, cares about the world…

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I take it you said no.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You think I’m that hung-up on rules and –

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: He’s not House. There’s nothing there.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Yeah, there is.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Did I ask you to plant a PPD?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It was positive, he’s got TB!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, of course he’s got TB! The guy’s been in the jungle for 20 years! If he tested positive for pink-eye would you think that was his big problem?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I did a test, it was positive, why is that a problem?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because now he’s got the big red target on his arm, the stubborn jerk thinks he’s right! He won’t let us do any more tests.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Well, maybe he’s not the only stubborn jerk. I did an LP2: low glucose and he has an increased sed rate. Everything screams tuberculosis!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not everything!

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: If any of the symptoms are caused by the TB it would throw off our diagnosis.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re right. Got to treat the TB.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Who knows, maybe he’ll just get better.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’d like that, wouldn’t you?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: So it’s TB, but not TB?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m complicated.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: The guy does know tuberculosis. If he says it can manifest itself –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He’s not even a real doctor, he’s a human telethon.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Is that your problem with him? You see hypocrites every day, why is this guy so special?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You think I have a hypocritical attitude to hypocrisy? The problem is there are 26 letters in the alphabet and he only uses two of them. He treats thousands of patients with one diagnosis. He knows the answer going in. It’s cheating.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: So it’s all because he’s one of them useless specialists?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, did I hurt the big time oncologist’s itty bitty feelings? You’re a big help to patients who actually have cancer. Other times you’re just annoying.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You’ve outdone yourself.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’ll say. My salad’s covering a free t-bone steak.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
